Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Advances in Discrete Networks
Award.AbstractNarration:
A workshop entitled, "Advances in Discrete Networks," will be held at the University of Pittsburgh on December 12-14, 2014. A network is a very general concept, encompassing any structure that can be represented as a collection of discrete nodes, some of which are joined by links called edges. An extremely broad variety of systems can be represented as networks; these range from man-made constructs such as power grids, the internet, and rigid structures, to abstract entities such as social interaction and disease contact networks, to biological systems such as neuronal or genetic networks. Mathematical and computational tools being developed to analyze such networks offer great potential for impact, given that the same mathematical framework can be used to represent such a wide diversity of systems.

The three-day workshop will provide a forum for the exchange of ideas relating to quantitative research about networks, pursued with a variety of perspectives and approaches. The event will bring together leading researchers in the field, with backgrounds in areas such as applied mathematics, mathematical biology, statistical physics, and computational methods, along with a diverse pool of graduate students, postdocs, and other scientists who are early in their careers. By doing so, it will highlight cutting edge advances in the analysis of network dynamics and structures, it will foster connections across mathematical areas and disciplines, and it will promote the involvement of junior researchers in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award helped to fund a workshop, "Advances in Discrete Networks", that was held at the University of Pittsburgh on December 12-14, 2014.  The workshop was attended by about 64 participants, including many trainees.  Fourteen talks were given and 17 posters were presented.  Funds from the award helped defray travel costs for 17 trainees (about 1/3 women and 2/3 men), consisting of 11 Ph.D. students, 5 postdocs, and 1 junior faculty member from a group that is underrepresented in the Mathematical Sciences. 

The workshop represented the culmination of the 2014 Fall Theme Semester on "Discrete Networks: Geometry, Dynamics and Applications" within the Department of Mathematics at Pitt.  Through its talks and associated discussions, it provided (1) an interdisciplinary view of the state of the art in research on discrete networks, including mathematical perspectives, computational tools, and applications to biological and other networks, and (2) ample opportunities for discussions and interactions among participants from diverse scientific fields, demographic groups, and career stages.  Scientifically, the presentations highlighted links across branches of mathematics and suggested new research approaches harnessing ideas from multiple areas. The webpage

http://www.math.pitt.edu/~lewicka/Semester_DiscrNetw_14/adv_disc_netw_workshop.html

provides the workshop schedule, presentation abstracts, a list of posters, a list of participants, and pdf files from the talks of those speakers who were willing to submit these documents.
